And wrinkled lip, and sneer of cold command,
Tell that its sculptor well those passions read
Which yet survive, stamped on these lifeless things,
The hand that mocked them, and the heart that fed;
And on the pedestal, these words appear:
My name is Ozymandias, King of Kings;
Look on my Works, ye Mighty, and despair!
Nothing beside remains. Round the decay
Of that colossal Wreck, boundless and bare
The lone and level sands stretch far away.‚Äù

text:
The payout of $1.8 billion dates to the 1970s, when Iran paid the U.S. $400 million for military equipment that was never delivered because the government was overthrown and diplomatic relations ruptured. That left people, 
businesses and governments in each country indebted to partners in the other, and these complex claims took decades to sort out in tribunals and arbitration. For its part, Iran paid settlements of more than $2.5  billion to U.S. citizens and businesses. The day after the nuclear deal was implemented, the U.S. and Iran announced they had settled the claim over the 1970s military equipment order, with the U.S. agreeing to pay the $400 million principal along with about $1.3 billion in interest. The $400 million was paid in cash and flown to Tehran on a cargo plane, which gave rise to Trump‚Äôs dramatic accounts of money stuffed in barrels or boxes and delivered in the dead of night. The arrangement provided for the interest to be paid later, not crammed into containers.Ôªø

text:
@32shumble, My assertion is valid. Deportation only went up because illegal immigration went up. But when you look at the statistics during the Bush and Obama administrations, Obama's deportation rate was miniscule compared to the amount of illegals that were coming over the border. Much of it had to do with the Catch and Release tactic. The fact of the matter is the dems in Congress have no clear answer for why they don't want border security (the wall) other than the claim that it will cost too much. But when presented with the facts that the cost is a drop in the bucket compared to the yearly government budget, it discourages crossings because it's a large physical obstacle, and the money saved from not having to hold and process illegals would easily pay for the wall and benefit the country as a whole, they have no argument. Pelosi is the most outspoken about the issue. You can listen to any one of her interviews regarding border security. She claims that it's "inhumane, immoral, and that these people have just as much of a right to be here". This, of course, is wrong. And when presented with facts and statistics, she has no further argument. There is NO argument for why we shouldn't have a border wall. The wall will be continued to be built. It will be finished. And America will prosper. 

Just as a side note: I have no problem with legal immigration. I just believe, as does the president,  that we should be able to choose the most beneficial people to come into this country. The problem is the entitled immigrants who feel that they don't need to follow the rules and can just come in whenever they pleaseÔªø
